column1: It is the capital of Tczew County in Pomeranian Voivodeship since 1999
column2: and was previously a town in Gdańsk Voivodeship (1975–1998). It is also the largest town of the ethnocultural region of Kociewie.

column1: The town is the location for the annual English Language Camp arranged by the American-Polish Partnership for Tczew.
Tczew is located on the west bank of river Vistula
column2: approximately 30 kilometres (19 miles) south of Gdańsk Bay at the Baltic Sea and 35 kilometres (22 miles) south-east of Gdańsk.

column3: ‘weaver's town’) was first mentioned as Trsow in a document by Pomeranian Duke Grzymisław bestowing the land to the Knights Hospitaller in 1198. Around 1200 Sambor I
column5: built a fortress here. In some documents
column7: which stems from the name of a feudal lord
column8: Dersław. It is unknown whether Trsow and Derszewo referred to the same or two neighboring settlements. In order to obtain better control of traffic on the Vistula
column9: Pomeranian Duke Sambor II moved his residence form Lubiszewo Tczewskie to Tczew. By 1252 the settlement was known by the names Tczew and Dirschau.

column1: In 1258 a city council was created and in 1260 Tczew was granted town rights. It is the only case in Poland for a city council to be established before granting city rights. Craft and trade developed
column2: there was a port on the Vistula and a mint. Duke Mestwin II in 1289 brought the Dominican Order to the city. It was part of Poland until 1308. Following the Treaty of Soldin in 1309
column3: Tczew was purchased from Brandenburg by Heinrich von Plötzke of the Teutonic Knights
column4: despite the fact that the initial claims to the region by Brandenburg were of dubious legality. The townspeople were expelled by the Teutonic Knights and the town's organization ceased to exist for more than half a century. It was rebuilt from 1364–1384
column5: and was granted Kulm law by Winrich von Kniprode. After the Polish victory in the Battle of Grunwald in 1410
column6: the town was briefly recaptured by Poland. In 1434 the town was burnt down by the Hussites. In 1440 the town joined the Prussian Confederation
column9: Bohemian mercenaries on the Order's service sold Tczew to Poland in lieu of indemnities. The Second Peace of Thorn (1466) confirmed the reincorporation of Tczew to Poland. It became a county seat within the Pomeranian Voivodeship in the newly created Polish province of Royal Prussia
column10: soon also part of the Greater Poland Province of the Polish Crown.

column1: During the Protestant Reformation most of town's inhabitants converted to Lutheranism. In 1626 it was occupied by king Gustav II Adolf of Sweden
column2: who built a pontoon bridge across river Vistula and who had his camp at the southern side of the town. After the war Tczew was visited twice by Polish King Władysław IV Vasa
column3: in 1634/1635 and 1636. Although it was rebuilt
column4: it then suffered during the Polish-Swedish Wars. In a nearby battle on 2 September 1657
column5: the Poles were defeated by the combined troops of Brandenburg and Sweden under general Josias II

column1: The region was annexed from the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth by the Kingdom of Prussia during the First Partition of Poland in 1772. Tczew
column3: became part of the newly founded Province of West Prussia. During the Napoleonic Wars and the Polish national liberation fights the town was captured by Polish troops of General Jan Henryk Dąbrowski in 1807
column4: but became Prussian again in 1815. In 1818 Prussians closed down the Dominican monastery. The town became part of the German Empire in 1871.

column1: The town grew rapidly during the 19th century after the opening of the Prussian Eastern Railway line connecting Berlin and Königsberg
column2: with the Vistula bridge near Dirschau being an important part.
the Polish population suffered from forced Germanization; for example Poles were denied Polish schools
column3: and refused to teach their children German. The German official Heinrich Mettenmeyer wrote that German-appointed teachers were treated with highest disdain by Polish children and their parents. The town remained a center of Polish resistance

column2: local Poles formed the People's Council in preparation for reintegration with Poland. After World War I as a consequence of the Treaty of Versailles Tczew became part of the so-called Polish Corridor and was incorporated into the re-established Polish state. On January 30
column4: Polish General Józef Haller arrived in the town with his troops. The town became a center of cultural activities of the German minority in Poland
column5: a German-language school and a theater was founded. The regional member of the Polish Parliament represented the German minority.

column2: Tczew was famous for its maritime academy (Szkoła Morska) which later moved to Gdynia.

Tczew was the location of the start of World War II when German bombers attacked Polish sapper installations to prevent the bridge from being blown up at 04:34 on 1 September 1939 (the shelling of Westerplatte commenced at 04:45).

column1: During the German occupation of Poland (1939–45) Tczew
column3: was annexed into Reichsgau Danzig-West Prussia of the administrative district of Regierungsbezirk Danzig of Germany's Third Reich. The Polish population was subjected to mass arrests
column5: expulsions and murder. The SS-Heimwehr-Sturmbann Götze entered the town in September 1939 to carry out actions against Poles
column6: including mass arrests with the help of local Germans organized in the Selbstschutz
column7: who denounced local Polish activists. The Germans imprisoned hundreds of Poles in camps established in a former factory (present-day museum)
column8: in a craft school and in military barracks. In November 1939
column9: Germans carried out executions of numerous Poles from Tczew
column14: and even a seventeen-year-old student. Catholic priests from Pelplin
column15: who were not murdered in Pelplin
column16: were imprisoned in the Tczew barracks and then murdered in the Szpęgawski Forest. In January 1940
column17: the SS and Selbstschutz carried out two public executions of 33 Polish residents
column21: at the market square. Also Poles from Starogard and Tuchola counties
column22: who refused to sign the Volksliste
column23: were imprisoned in Tczew and then murdered in a nearby forest.

column2: the Germans created a transition camp for Poles expelled from the region in a local factory (present-day museum). People were held there for several weeks
column3: and then expelled to the General Government. Hundreds of Polish inhabitants of Tczew were expelled in 1940 and 1941. Some inhabitants were also deported to forced labour to Germany.After World War II the town
column4: was one of the most damaged cities of Gdańsk Pomerania. Virtually none of its remaining factories were capable of production. There had been considerable loss of population down to around 18-20 thousand people. Shortly before the end of World War II it was occupied by the Soviet Army. After the end of war the town became part of People's Republic of Poland and renamed Tczew again. German residents were dispossessed and expelled; Polish residents took the first effort of reconstruction

The coat of arms of Tczew depicts a red griffin in honor of Duke Sambor II

column1: Parish Church of the Holy Cross – situated in the centre of the Old Town
column2: by Wyszyńskiego street. It is the oldest building in Tczew. The church was built in the 13th century and features a Baroque interior. The high brick tower is the oldest part of the church and its wooden top was destroyed during the fire in 1982. The interior church walls feature old frescoes
column3: the oldest of which dates back to the latter half of the 15th century.

column1: Bridges on the Vistula River – located by Jana z Kolna street and the Vistula boulevard are Tczew's main sights. The road bridge was the first one to be constructed
column3: with its 837 metres’ length
column4: it was one of the longest bridges in the world. Originally
column5: the bridge had ten towers and two gateways – today only four towers remain. The other
column8: when one bridge was no longer sufficient. On 1 September 1939 at 5:30AM
column9: the bridges were destroyed by Polish sappers in order to prevent the German Army from accessing the city from the other side of the Vistula River. The bridges were rebuilt in 1940 and destroyed again in 1945 by the Germans. The final reconstruction of the bridges took place between 1958 and 1959.

column1: Museum of the Vistula River – situated by 30 Stycznia street
column2: in the pre-war agricultural machine factory where during World War II
column3: a transitional camp for Poles expelled from the region was established and operated by Nazi Germany. Then
column4: the gas-meter factory operated in the building and after this the first museum of the Vistula River was established. In 2007
column5: the building was renovated and now operates as the Museum of the Vistula River and Regional Centre of the Lower Vistula. It is a branch of the National Maritime Museum in Gdańsk.

column1: Water Tower – located on the corner of 30 Stycznia and Bałdowska streets. It was built in 1905. The water tower presents former architectural style of municipal facilities. The 40-metre-high tower with the power of natural pressure distributed the water to the houses.
Town Hall – the old town hall was situated in Hallera square
column2: in the centre of the Old Town. It was destroyed during the fire in 1916 and has never been rebuilt since. Now only the outline of the former town hall can be seen in the square. The new town hall was built in the Piłsudskiego square in the early 20th century.

column1: Dutch-type windmill – situated by Wojska Polskiego street. It was built in 1806. The windmill is wooden with brick foundations and has rarely seen five sails and a rotary head.
Post Office – situated on the corner of Dąbrowskiego and Obrońców Westerplatte streets. It is the oldest post office in Tczew
column2: built in 1905. On the front wall we can see the crests of Gdańsk and Tczew and also the Polish state emblem.

column1: The building of former Naval School – located by Szkoły Morskiej street. Built in 1911. At the beginning the girls’ school was situated there and later
column3: it was the location of the first Naval School in Poland which was later moved to Gdynia. Nowadays
column4: the building houses a secondary school.

column1: The building of former municipal baths – situated on Łazienna street. Built in 1913. Now the powiat council is based in this building.
Municipal Park – located in the centre of Tczew
column3: Bałdowska
column4: and Sienkiewicza streets occupies the area of 37 acres (15 ha). The lower part of the park arose in the second part of the 19th century
column5: the upper part in the 20th century. In the park you can see an amphitheatre where
column7: many concerts take place. By the entrance to the park a monument of Tczew's scouts killed during the World War II is situated.

The two most notable sports clubs of the town are Unia Tczew (football and rowing) and Wisła Tczew (football and boxing).

column2: the town has been the host location for the annual English Language Camp. The camp
column3: often nicknamed "Camp Tczew" is hosted by the American-Polish Partnership for Tczew and offers students a three-week program where they have the opportunity to interact with Americans and improve their English.
